subject: linear_algebra
title: Row Operations and Determinants
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how row operations affect determinants.
problemHtml:
Consider a matrix A with determinant det(A) = 2. Perform the following row operations:
\[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 3 \\ 2 & 4\end{bmatrix}\] becomes \[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 2 & 2\end{bmatrix}\] by subtracting the first row from the second. What is det(A) after this operation?",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Apply the row operation", "mathHtml": "\[\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 2-2 & 2\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We're simply performing a series of elementary row operations to transform A into another matrix."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Find the determinant of the new matrix", "mathHtml": "\[\det\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2\end{bmatrix}\] = 2"}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Use the fact that det(AB) = det(A)det(B)", "mathHtml": "\[\det(A)\det\begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 2\end{bmatrix}\]"}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Combine the results", "mathHtml": "\[2 \cdot 2 = 4\]"} ],
intuition: Row operations can significantly change the determinant of a matrix. This example illustrates how the determinant is preserved under certain transformations.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Row Operations and Determinant Properties
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll explore how row operations affect determinants and their properties.
problemHtml: Find the determinant of the matrix <math>\[ \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\]</math> after applying the following row operation: swap rows 1 and 2.",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Apply the row operation", "mathHtml": "<math>\[ \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]</math>", "explanation": "We swap rows 1 and 2 to obtain a new matrix."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Calculate the determinant of the new matrix", "mathHtml": "<math>\[ \det(\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}) = (-1) (4 - 2) = -2\]</math>", "explanation": "The determinant is calculated as the product of the diagonal entries minus the product of the off-diagonal entries."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Show that the determinant remains unchanged under row operations", "mathHtml": "<math>\[ \det(\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}) = -2\]</math>", "explanation": "The determinant is invariant under row operations, which allows us to simplify calculations and solve problems more efficiently."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Calculate the determinant of the original matrix", "mathHtml": "<math>\[ \det(\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}) = -2\]</math>", "explanation": "The determinant of the original matrix is the same as that of the transformed matrix, demonstrating the property."}, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Conclude that row operations do not change the determinant", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "Row operations do not affect the value of the determinant, making it a useful tool for solving systems of linear equations."} ],
intuition: The key insight is that row operations preserve the determinant, allowing us to simplify calculations and solve problems more efficiently.

title: Row Operations and Determinant Properties
contentHtml: In this example, we'll explore how row operations affect determinants and their properties.
problemHtml: Find the determinant of the matrix \[\begin{bmatrix}2 & 3 \\ 1 & 4\end{bmatrix}\] after applying the following row operations:",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Swap rows 1 and 2", "mathHtml": "\[ \begin{bmatrix}4 & 3 \\ 2 & 1\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We're swapping the rows to see how it affects the determinant."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Multiply row 1 by -2", "mathHtml": "\[ \begin{bmatrix}-8 & -6 \\ 2 & 1\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We're multiplying the first row to see how it affects the determinant."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Add row 2 to row 1", "mathHtml": "\[ \begin{bmatrix}-6 & -5 \\ 2 & 1\end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "We're adding the second row to the first row to see how it affects the determinant."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "The determinant remains unchanged", "mathHtml": "", "explanation": "Despite these row operations, the determinant remains the same because they don't change the underlying linear transformation."} ],
intuition: Row operations can be used to simplify matrices, but they don't affect the determinant. This property makes determinants useful for solving systems of linear equations and finding the inverse of a matrix.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Row Operations and Determinants
contentHtml: In this example, we'll explore how row operations affect determinants.

hints: Apply row operations to simplify the determinant
problem.solutionHtml:
To find the determinant, we can apply row operations:

  • Step 1: Swap rows 1 and 2.
    • \[A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\]
  • Step 2: Multiply row 1 by -1.
    • \[-A = \begin{bmatrix} -3 & -4 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\]
  • Step 3: Add 3 times row 1 to row 2.
    • \[A = \begin{bmatrix} -3 & -4 \\ -8 & -10 \end{bmatrix}\]

    The determinant remains unchanged under these operations.
